4C859132340148F8BA3A8074608199FA.description: research and describe advances in science and medicine at the cellular level such as stem cells and gene therapy.

A1D91B02D9FE449181F5E393BE55869F.description: research and discuss advances in science and medicine at the organ and tissue level such as bionics and wearable monitoring technologies; and

9AF2397D4E9E4B709F9322F4C7C99A07.description: Emerging technologies. The student identifies emerging technological advances in science and healthcare treatment and delivery. The student is expected to:

FD9DE53B500544C091F479FF4762BFFF.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the reproductive system such as sexually transmitted diseases and cancers of the female and male reproductive systems.

B0F04229AD45402A9C2A1C89432F9791.description: identify and distinguish the hormones involved in maturation and development throughout the life cycle, including puberty, gestation, and menopause; and

CB3B24563FC846019C455F54E1328A50.description: research and discuss the physiological effects of hormones on the stages of the menstrual cycle;

3D702FF89C5C4FD7821FCDC5DCC2860E.description: describe and compare the process of oogenesis and spermatogenesis;

E725A4D99E6341E38ACAD03308BB92E4.description: describe and examine the location, structure, and functions of the internal and external female and male reproductive organs and accessory glands;

EE6BF025E67749488986D30E8D41C16F.description: explain embryological development of cells, tissues, organs, and systems;

39549A989E3C46868CE6728661FF1073.description: Reproductive system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the reproductive system. The student is expected to:

9EA69CE3DB1B4ED58BA966CDD578573F.description: identify and describe common diseases of the respiratory system such as asthma, emphysema, pneumonia, viruses, and allergies.

0BA046E479784DC4BF5953FF7A7C504A.description: investigate factors that affect respiration, including exercise and environmental changes such as altitude; and

C86867F263AC47A69803E42DFEDFCAAA.description: describe the relationship between the respiratory and cardiovascular systems during pulmonary circulation;

FD9C74D4C0694398A3F15E7A9B4B58B1.description: describe the physiology of respiration, including internal and external respiration and gas exchange;

8F17C0CF86374ADEA2BB868C5454FF76.description: compare and contrast the functions of upper and lower respiratory tract;

C8DB3CC7EDDE475A873083BA29BB5A81.description: identify and sequence the anatomical structures and functions of the respiratory system;

932F1690A9814059AA041E356DCC414B.description: Respiratory system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the respiratory system. The student is expected to:

0ADFE4C6B4CB4135B808F46DC7A638F7.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the digestive system such as gallstones, Crohn's disease, irritable bowel syndrome, and gastroesophageal reflux disorder.

3F4BAEF280C146BFA51C0E3FD6FEF946.description: evaluate the modes by which energy is processed and stored within the body, including ingestion, propulsion, absorption, and elimination; and

277814A3352249938B6DD06BADBAA925.description: compare and contrast mechanical and chemical digestive processes;

284890D154944E359106B1F0C283FBC7.description: examine the anatomical structures and function of the alimentary canal and accessory organs;

4202DC9E86D94C7A9AFDA96D95F55CF0.description: Digestive system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the digestive system. The student is expected to:

D7322CF017C5412F946DF0CCB56E8A7C.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders associated with the lymphatic and immune systems such as inherited or acquired immunodeficiencies, autoimmune diseases, and lymphomas.

0C3412B2DA444D2CAC12154A08D73988.description: describe the role of antigens and antibodies in the immune response; and

1909E8EE261E4FB3A4867B14E341794A.description: summarize the ways the body protects and defends against disease, including inflammation, barrier defenses, and active and passive immunity;

C439A1A31F1B4F7CA4E8CF3B85BDB845.description: identify and determine antigens associated with ABO blood typing, including Rhesus (Rh) factor;

40FF1DAEBA2E457CB048FD4B7F6BE278.description: identify and describe the role and function of the immune cells, including T cells and B cells, within the lymphatic system structures;

30952D1BB027474C9ADC31504460A7F0.description: describe the structure and function of the lymphatic organs and explain how lymph moves through the body;

13442317DE394F61A90A25A6B2F1D37D.description: evaluate the interaction of the lymphatic system with other body systems such as the circulatory system;

008A6CDEFA3F4896AB922658ED3D0C22.description: Lymphatic system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the lymphatic system and understands the immune response. The student is expected to:

70A72BC1D4554BB08163E5335E4488A4.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the cardiovascular system such as heart disease, myocardial infarction, ischemia, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

14F546268A894C288736913D2C8A2920.description: describe the relationship between the cardiovascular system, nervous system, and muscular system in regulating cardiac output; and

4244427F995E4AB2A09A67B7AD51054C.description: illustrate how the PQRST waves of an electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrate the conduction of electricity through the structures of the heart;

913ACC7874C14C9B82F9989F26C71463.description: compare and contrast coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulation, and describe the major vessels of each;

BA5AF7DB045A45AEA1769E8ED786544A.description: describe the relationship between blood flow and blood pressure, including systolic and diastolic pressure, pulse pressure, and mean arterial pressure;

BAE76346226A44B7994011E6534DFF3A.description: investigate and illustrate how systemic circulation transports blood, gasses, and nutrients from the heart to the internal anatomy of the heart, including tissue layers, chambers, and valves, and external anatomy of the heart, including coronary vessels;

0F9105A256744BA99E90A423E5E4A61F.description: compare and contrast the anatomical structure of arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins;

78065C7BB9A14C7BB77208397002FB74.description: identify the major functions of the cardiovascular system, including transport, maintaining homeostasis, and immune response;

A0301A879DB143CB85F3227F072D4432.description: Cardiovascular system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the cardiovascular system. The student is expected to:

D969B944ED8A492E89BE29CD0398C49D.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the urinary system such as chronic kidney disease, kidney stones, urinary tract infections, and renal cancer.

C88E99C05ECD4CBD82419E8ACE5CB057.description: describe the relationship between the nervous system, renal system, and muscular system before and during micturition; and

87F3C6ECB74B483799AF19EAD54A5B26.description: analyze the composition of urine and the process of urine formation, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion;

B5B335DC182848A7AEEBADA638FA17A0.description: examine the methods of fluid balance and homeostasis in the urinary system, including fluid intake and output;

ED80241D237643DAABA60C6919723C7E.description: summarize and illustrate the structures, functions, and types of nephrons;

C9CEAA59578B4337A6A5B71F991D9103.description: compare and contrast the anatomical structures and describe the functions of the male and female urinary system;

6F91BB77561745528067D00530E7CB84.description: identify and describe the anatomical structures and functions of the urinary system, including the kidney, ureters, bladder, and urethra;

74A9C652800944229119559159E13EB5.description: Urinary system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the urinary system. The student is expected to:

9327FE3E199F4B8B84748E87DF0F6E3A.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the endocrine system such as hypothyroidism, pancreatic cancer, and diabetes.

9EAFF2936B0644B8BF8A07B173350531.description: explain how the endocrine glands are regulated, including neural, hormonal, and humoral control; and

F71CF830ECF04125A6F129148D55AF19.description: research the impact of the endocrine systems on homeostatic mechanisms and other body systems such as the integration between the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland;

9F502B7325E043758AC8B60BBE5D15D5.description: describe the hormones associated with each endocrine gland;

B3A70188AE484EC0B04F0A95EA1F4A21.description: compare and contrast endocrine and exocrine glands and identify the glands associated with each;

1169B1C31ADE4EDF936B2DE8D36686E5.description: identify and locate the nine glands associated with the endocrine system, including the ovaries, testes, pineal gland, pituitary gland, thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, thymus, pancreas, and adrenal glands;

840978D40B324FE18E8837704A9B6916.description: Endocrine system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the endocrine system. The student is expected to:

0E62EEC0D94540CEA7E9A6CD7FA9AB7A.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the nervous system such as epilepsy, neuralgia, Parkinson's disease, and Alzheimer's disease.

1178F069865B47F08DA4CDF40D5888C4.description: categorize the major neurotransmitters by chemical and physical mechanisms; and

A6A36B252DC64EC4A359B9C2CF74E4FE.description: distinguish between the types of neurons and explain the initiation of a nerve impulse during resting and action potential;

B0C7F4D3D46B42EEB2C5AEA83723D448.description: analyze the functional and structural differences between gray and white matter relative to neurons;

450677EA714E429982D01024CCE0E4B0.description: explain the glial cells within the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system and their associated functions;

2718108BAE6A4B0C9DE016F8B8A6D579.description: identify the anatomical and physiological divisions of the peripheral nervous system and central nervous system;

F78B4D1DBA8B48ADA7A76A7363FAE9F7.description: describe the anatomy of the structures associated with the senses, including vision, hearing, smell, taste, and touch;

DA232D365D2B4C3A8907AEEC059492D7.description: investigate and explain the interdependence between the cranial and spinal nerves with the special senses of vision, hearing, smell, and taste;

DEC0BB0D7BEC42F283ACAC84FD818C5D.description: identify the senses and explain their relationship to nervous system;

3C0D8A56E0F84CBA89AA205FF85C74AA.description: summarize and distinguish between the major physiological functions of the nervous system, including sensation, integration, and motor response;

92B3FDDBA9CD431BA31E1FBC1ECDA407.description: Nervous system. The student analyzes the relationship between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the nervous system. The student is expected to:

C6AE5D247ED5446A8666ECC5A579957B.description: analyze and describe the effects of pressure, movement, torque, tension, and elasticity on the human body.

4D5AA4309FAF491B906498FD768DFE75.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the muscular system such as muscle strains and muscular dystrophy; and

31E1A4FE5A1841979E6589EA6BB021E0.description: name, locate, and describe the action of major voluntary muscles in regions of the body, including the head and neck, trunk, upper extremity, and lower extremity;

6B3CDB07CBDD4131BDADCDBE3A90DA8F.description: describe the mechanisms of muscle contraction at the neuromuscular junction;

CC6A1E1736BB4F40969A6F66996EB845.description: examine the microscopic anatomy of a muscle fiber, including sarcomere, actin, and myosin;

2F13ED18B3114E869CAD6A863770E320.description: identify and describe the appearance, innervation, and function of the three muscle types, including cardiac, skeletal, and smooth;

617D24069547480B8F1503EE9CB00137.description: examine common characteristics of muscle tissue, including excitability, contractibility, extensibility, and elasticity;

53230E0F2A194BDEA343AB0C221DCDC5.description: explain the coordination of muscles, bones, and joints that allows movement of the body, including the methods of attachment of ligaments and tendons;

FF20AC5804F64CD790240B3F5FF563B4.description: explain the major physiological functions of the muscular system, including voluntary movement, involuntary movement, heat production, and maintaining posture;

806337ADD0BE4ECE8A9E8761DCFA1B52.description: Muscular system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the muscular system. The student is expected to:

F7B6FB6784354443A4205E26E8C02875.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the integumentary system such as skin cancer and psoriasis.

EB0CE03ED43540B18BABF257C84F60CE.description: describe and explain the process of tissue repair and scar formation; and

04EE31F13F8A49419EB8DF48E2B92430.description: describe the factors that can contribute to skin color;

F0FAD4B5CD5B44C88C8DB6287BDE5AF8.description: identify and describe the structures of the integumentary system, including layers of the skin, accessory organs within each layer, and glandular components in each layer;

F9D18138C58B4BEFBFF70ECC3EE5325E.description: Integumentary system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the integumentary system. The student is expected to:

56A99B4065224B2E81CD21D083637353.description: identify and describe common diseases and disorders of the skeletal system such as scoliosis, osteoporosis, and bone cancer.

6F97D9F16A4D487C9E458683BF163BE1.description: identify and describe the different types of fractures such as compound, complete, simple, spiral, greenstick, hairline, transverse, and comminuted; and

34BA28CD2D364354BFFA567DDCBF29AD.description: describe the role of osteoblasts, osteocytes, and osteoclasts in bone growth and repair;

CB29A90286194DAD8EA79541D12AC9C9.description: explain the major physiological functions of the skeletal system;

FB344FAC66284003880BAD1D0C99A429.description: identify and locate the anatomy of bone, including spongy and compact tissue, epiphysis, diaphysis, medullary cavity, periosteum, bone marrow, and endosteum;

3236B4C1EA93422A958A1C1EA02D5BAC.description: identify the types of joints, including gliding, hinge, pivot, saddle, and ball and socket, and describe the movements of each;

5CE9444916B044A68C12FEDDAD386A50.description: identify and differentiate between the axial skeleton and appendicular skeleton;

56A2EA8F567E412DBDDF857C4B655B21.description: Skeletal system. The student analyzes the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of the skeletal system. The student is expected to:

F2E638424C8C49EE8BE7208967A628AD.description: describe the general metabolic pathways of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins.

8C95F3337E8E4F8A8A4117D19C3DA293.description: describe the process of tissue repair involved in the normal healing of a superficial wound; and

23937C32703E44298153B71BFECF6CF0.description: compare epithelial tissue and connective tissue in terms of cell arrangement and interstitial materials;

A455802A65474237A303586258CC9B9E.description: define tissue and identify the four primary tissue types, their subdivisions, and functions;

4B8D8048FC344E708E1472A7C5DCE4DC.description: Histology. The student demonstrates the ability to analyze the structure and function of eukaryotic cells in relation to the formation of tissue. The student is expected to:

045968152C124222A8E4ADD83A5ACBE0.description: research and identify the effects of the failure to maintain homeostasis as it relates to common diseases in each of the body systems.

CE593F010D6E487BA224252E01A4EC39.description: research and describe negative and positive feedback loops as they apply to homeostasis; and

8B4AA24DC484438C83AF591DE29B9029.description: identify and describe the major characteristics of living organisms, including response to stimuli, growth and development, homeostasis, cellular composition, metabolism, reproduction, and the ability to adapt to the environment;

BD79CC257C2942F3918499D212388895.description: identify and use appropriate directional terminology when referring to the human body, including directional terms, planes, body cavities, and body quadrants;

34C2C3AB908045468115EA99BDA1BDA8.description: distinguish between the six levels of structural organization in the human body, including chemical, cellular, tissue, organ, system, and organism, and explain their interdependence;

46F754B5BFFE4BCCBB9256F4316CBF2C.description: Human body organization. The student demonstrates an understanding of the anatomic and physiological basis of life and the ability to explain the interdependence of structure and function in biological systems. The student is expected to:

D0E80D5872F641EBA4D53C5FE059EE9A.description: research and explore resources such as museums, libraries, professional organizations, private companies, online platforms, and mentors employed in a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) or health science field in order to investigate careers.

C9648D1FD8A64FC5ADA68BE5AB6B28B5.description: relate the impact of past and current research on scientific thought and society, including research methodology, cost-benefit analysis, and contributions of diverse scientists and engineers as related to the content; and

6607AC81241C41569DE6262233C24CCC.description: analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations and solutions by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

6BC91C46BEC145258F46F02CF0A050E5.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student knows the contributions of scientists and engineers and recognizes the importance of scientific research and innovation on society. The student is expected to:

C2ED1334A86A47DAABF743A4E4C9D3ED.description: engage respectfully in scientific argumentation using applied scientific explanations and empirical evidence.

EE20B376BBA942CD94C531174F33324E.description: communicate explanations and solutions individually and collaboratively in a variety of settings and formats; and

5A7100A44B6F4037B551EE4F5936FA40.description: develop explanations and propose solutions supported by data and models and consistent with scientific ideas, principles, and theories;

CA2AEF8F57914B5597B3F14159CEA6AF.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student develops evidence-based explanations and communicates findings, conclusions, and proposed solutions. The student is expected to:

3AD19A9EAE2C44ED8826C38B9AEBA4F9.description: use mathematical calculations to assess quantitative relationships in data; and

EEAC9EA09E9746799AEDA99F06106F2A.description: analyze data by identifying significant statistical features, patterns, sources of error, and limitations;

47873F30790440A99832A5E3E7C41F18.description: identify advantages and limitations of models such as their size, scale, properties, and materials;

52958DDC5C9748A395865F3C7ADD1837.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student analyzes and interprets data to derive meaning, identify features and patterns, and discover relationships or correlations to develop evidence-based arguments or evaluate designs. The student is expected to:

63C7E59A7DBC4E3DA01C1231351FA0BE.description: distinguish among scientific hypotheses, theories, and laws.

AC15DF91CE1B40F092280F72FB98A5E3.description: develop and use models to represent phenomena, systems, processes, or solutions to engineering problems; and

E886BCB6960C4C7995949BF246C56C81.description: organize quantitative and qualitative data using lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports;

29479DCB549D444383168A679F2E0740.description: collect quantitative data using the International System of Units (SI) and United States customary units and qualitative data as evidence;

CDE88F906B7D4CA8A749E6B31FFCCF48.description: use appropriate tools such as lab notebooks or journals, calculators, spreadsheet software, data-collecting probes, computers, standard laboratory glassware, microscopes, various prepared slides, stereoscopes, metric rulers, meter sticks, electronic balances, micro pipettors, hand lenses, Celsius thermometers, hot plates, timing devices, Petri dishes, agar, lab incubators, dissection equipment, reflex hammers, pulse oximeters, stethoscope, otoscope, blood pressure monitors (sphygmomanometers), pen lights, ultrasound equipment, and models, diagrams, or samples of biological specimens or structures;

3B2AAC8C2C55401BBE0FA9E3A915A463.description: use appropriate safety equipment and practices during laboratory, classroom, and field investigations as outlined in Texas Education Agency-approved safety standards;

F87697B8A31449E1B74688D8C0A795C6.description: apply scientific practices to plan and conduct descriptive, comparative, and experimental investigations and use engineering practices to design solutions to problems;

353F4C3EF6E84337ACE28945E157B2C1.description: ask questions and define problems based on observations or information from text, phenomena, models, or investigations;

4A51DB2ED17C4E86AA337677FBEB08B4.description: Scientific and engineering practices. The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, asks questions, identifies problems, and plans and safely conducts classroom, laboratory, and field investigations to answer questions, explain phenomena, or design solutions using appropriate tools and models. The student is expected to:

7DA09A6F620249A58442B4ACD71B90E7.description: investigate necessary skills for heath careers related to anatomy and physiology.

4847C0C648B24C91B510F6D5E4EE31D2.description: exhibit the ability to cooperate, contribute, and collaborate as a member of a team; and

C72C7F9EE1524BDBAA5363039E91E67D.description: demonstrate verbal and non-verbal communication in a clear, concise, and effective manner;

A55BFE2172424D348D45D96C4B1E7793.description: Employability skills. The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and industry. The student is expected to:

4FAD3F8694A048789EF11F94B8EC471B.description: Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

16489134F8794FA98ADC65C16C8F23CF.description: Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

EA87DB3D18434A54A0A7DB56FDDD22F7.description: Science consists of recurring themes and making connections between overarching concepts. Recurring themes include systems, models, and patterns. All systems have basic properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested, while models allow for boundary specification and provide a tool for understanding the ideas presented. Students should analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

11C120BAA0424B3FA18CE22D7F004635.description: Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world involving its own set of ethical standards about how the process of science should be carried out. Students should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods (scientific methods) and ethical and social decisions that involve science (the application of scientific information).

50F2219E87C64464A0A442AA7F9E1802.description: Engineering practices. Students should be able to identify problems and design solutions using appropriate tools and models.

1BEE77CF837D479F8F62FC7358700623.description: Scientific practices. Students should be able to ask questions, plan and conduct investigations to answer questions, and explain phenomena using appropriate tools and models.

7253774A2F9343E48B114E312A9B44C7.description: Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world using scientific and engineering practices. Scientific methods of investigation are descriptive, comparative, or experimental. The method chosen should be appropriate to the question being asked. Student learning for different types of investigations include descriptive investigations, which involve collecting data and recording observations without making comparisons; comparative investigations, which involve collecting data with variables that are manipulated to compare results; and experimental investigations, which involve processes similar to comparative investigations but in which a control is identified.

46DA77A20A2941F3A6ECED5D138A4721.description: scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well established and highly reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science and new technologies are developed.

2682D5D502C64F8396442EE57750C65B.description: hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories; and

CC064E6FC926477D9CF634145CB90D5E.description: Students are expected to know that:

A22F9BC15E6F427685FA665D125BEDCF.description: Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not currently scientifically testable.

717C2A2C70454CAFB5453BD24B55F29F.description: The Anatomy and Physiology course is designed for students to conduct laboratory and field investigations, use scientific methods during investigations, and make informed decisions using critical thinking and scientific problem solving. Students in Anatomy and Physiology will study a variety of topics, including the structure and function of the human body and the interaction of body systems for maintaining homeostasis.

9493C6DD761349489E343BCA3E32DDEE.description: The Health Science Career Cluster focuses on planning, managing, and providing therapeutic services, diagnostic services, health informatics, support services, and biotechnology research and development.

28B755200D58433DA751DDDDFD1C2FB8.description: Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards, industry-relevant technical knowledge, and college and career readiness skills for students to further their education and succeed in current and emerging professions.

312B7ECAD8154E9AB43342FBBDEE73BE.description: General requirements. This course is recommended for students in Grades 10-12. Prerequisite: one credit in biology and one credit in chemistry, Integrated Physics and Chemistry, or physics. Recommended prerequisite: a course from the Health Science Career Cluster. This course satisfies a high school science graduation requirement. Students shall be awarded one credit for successful completion of this course.

63A3C296E52041E581C2F610CDE069F9.description: If the commissioner does not make the determination that instructional materials funding has been made available under this subsection, the commissioner shall determine no later than August 31 of each subsequent school year whether instructional materials funding has been made available. If the commissioner determines that instructional materials funding has been made available, the commissioner shall notify the State Board of Education and school districts that this section shall be implemented for the following school year.

135BC75C830442A785B2FB5E21AF8681.description: If the commissioner makes the determination that instructional materials funding has been made available, this section shall be implemented beginning with the 2024-2025 school year and apply to the 2024-2025 and subsequent school years.

D777BC2905E04807A45963D09AF100F5.description: No later than August 31, 2024, the commissioner of education shall determine whether instructional materials funding has been made available to Texas public schools for materials that cover the essential knowledge and skills identified in this section.

AE279B2AF45A465193A16896B47D6988.description: Implementation. The provisions of this section shall be implemented by school districts beginning with the 2024-2025 school year.
